action.content:
You are playing a negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the score you receive.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

2 threads, 3 bolts, 1 picture

Your secret value function is:

thread: 0, bolt: 1, picture: 7

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.
action.label: context

action.content:
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out how to split these items with the other player. Let me see, the items are 2 threads, 3 bolts, and 1 picture. My secret values are thread: 0, bolt: 1, and picture: 7. Hmm, that means the picture is super valuable to me, while threads are worthless. Bolts are just okay, but not as good as the picture.

The other player has their own value function, which I don't know yet. I need to negotiate a deal where both of us can get items such that the total is complementing each other's proposals. If we can't, we both get zero, which isn't good. So I should try to maximize my own score, but also make sure that the other player is happy enough to agree.

Wait, but I can make a message to the other player first to test the waters. Maybe I can say something like, "I'm willing to let you have the majority of the bolts if you let me have the picture." Alternatively, I can just make the proposal directly if I think it's the best. Let me think about the possible combinations.

First, I need to prioritize which items are most valuable to me. The picture gives me the highest value at 4, followed by each thread at 3. Bolts are worth 0 to me, so I don't really care about those. My main goal is to secure the picture and as many threads as possible.
